entries.definition: The conceiving of oneself as an "I," or ego, which Hinduism considers a state to be transcended.
"Desire; will."
A sacred image, usually of God or one of the Gods. English for murti.

Literally "icon breaker." Also, opposed to the worship or use of religious icons, or advocating their destruction. Metaphorically: irreverently opposed to, or disparaging widely accepted ideas, beliefs and customs.
Inner body nadi current, pink in color, that flows downward ending on the left side of the body. This current is feminine in nature, radiating a physical, emotional energy.
"Soothing channel." The feminine psychic current flowing along the spine.
People, places, things (such as the body and the individual mind) or positions with which one may identify oneself.
A set of doctrines or beliefs that form the basis of a system of thought, often used to mean narrow-minded or uncritical adherence to such a system.
"Sugar cane."
"Sugar cane bow." A weapon or emblem held by loving Ganesha.
Impossible to limit or circumscribe; endless.
A belief, opinion or observation that appears to be, but is not in accord with the facts, truth or true values, such as the illusion created by a magician.
Very luminous or bright; distinguished, famous; outstanding.
(Shum) No awareness, state beyond that of singular awareness. Not a word for Self Realization, but the entry into that nonexperience. Pronounced eem-kaw-eef.
Free from stain or blemish; pure.

Indwelling; inherent and operating within. Relating to God, the term immanent means present in all things and throughout the universe, not aloof or distant. Not to be confused with imminent, threatening (about) to happen; emanate, to issue from; eminent, high in rank.
Not ripe; not fully grown, undeveloped. Still young.  -- immature soul:
From a time so distant that it extends beyond history or human memory.
Threatening to happen without delay; impending.
Sacrifice. Offer as sacrifice.
Never changing or varying.
A dead end; a point of no progress; stalemate. A difficulty with no solution.
To obstruct or delay something; make difficult to accomplish. (Noun form: impediment.)
That which "holds the feet." Hindrance; obstacle. Anything that inhibits or slows progress.
About to happen; "overhanging" and thus threatening.
That which cannot die or decay; indestructible; immortal. With capital I, Imperishable denotes God -- the Eternal, Beginningless and Endless.
The quality of being temporary and nonlasting.
Not personal; not connected to any person.

One's innermost nature, at the level of the soul's essence, where one is not distinguished as an individual, nor as separate from God or any part of existence. The soul's essential being -- Satchidananda and Parashiva.

God in His perfections of Pure Consciousness (Parashakti) and Absolute Reality beyond all attributes (Parashiva) wherein He is not a person. (Whereas, in His third perfection, Parameshvara, Siva is someone, has a body and performs actions, has will, dances, etc.)
Incapable of being affected or penetrated.
Anything that stimulates activity. Driving force; motive, incentive.
To establish securely, as in the mind or consciousness; instill.
To ask, beg, beseech or entreat earnestly or pathetically.
Forcing (oneself, for example) on another or others. Impressive, admirable, by virtue of size or power.
Poor; reduced to a condition of severe deprivation.
To saturate or fill; permeate. Make pregnant.
A sudden wish or urge that prompts an unplanned act or feeling.
A state of immorality, pollution or sin. Uncleanliness.
Unequal to what is required, unable to meet a need.
Begun, especially officially or formally.
Not favorable. Not a good time to perform certain actions or undertake projects. Ill-omened.
fixed in the character or disposition as if inherited by birth; deep-seated.
Glowing with heat; white-hot. Radiant; luminous; very bright.
To chant, repeat or recite mantras.

Mantraprayoga. The chanting of prayers, verses or formulas for magical or mystical purposes. Also refers to such chants (mantra). Vashakriya is the subduing or bewitching by charms, incantation or drugs. Incantation for malevolent purposes (black magic) is called abhichara.
To put into jail. To shut in; confine.

From incarnate, "made flesh." The soul's taking on a human body.  -- divine incarnation: The concept of avatara. The Supreme Being's (or other Mahadeva's) taking of human birth, generally to reestablish dharma. This doctrine is important to several Hindu sects, notably Vaishnavism, but not held by most Saivites.

Dhupa. Substance that gives off pleasant aromas when burned, usually made from natural substances such as tree resin. A central element in Hindu worship rites, waved gently before the Deity as an offering, especially after ablution. Hindi terms include sugandhi and lobana. A popular term for stick incense is agarbatti (Gujarati).
Continuing without interruption.
"Cutting into." Sharp or keen, such as a penetrating and discriminating mind.
Without being recognized; keeping one's true identity unrevealed or disguised.
Difficult or impossible to understand.
Not readily noticeable; transparent; insignificant.
An amount of increase, usually small and followed by others; a measure of growth or change.
Impossible to remove, erase, or wash away; permanent.
Intrinsic; innate; native.
Impoverished; poor; needy; destitute.
A dark blue to grayish purple blue color.
Not clearly or sharply defined, vague; difficult to understand.

A term used to describe the soul's nature as a unique entity, emanated by God Siva (the Primal Soul), as a being which is evolving through experience to its fully mature state, which is complete, indistinguishable oneness with God.
Quality that makes one person or soul other than, or different from, another.
To imbue with a partisan or ideological point of view.
Not easily discouraged, defeated or subdued. Unconquerable.
"Ruler." Vedic God of rain and thunder, warrior king of the devas. A great, inner-plane being who is invoked in hundreds of Vedic hymns.

"Agent, sense organ." The five agents of perception (jnanendriyas), hearing (shrotra), touch (tvak), sight (chakshus), taste (rasana) and smell (ghrana); and the five agents of action (karmendriyas), speech (vak), grasping, by means of the hands (pani), movement (pada), excretion (payu) and generation (upastha).
To bring about, cause, persuade.
Deriving general principles from particular facts or instances.
Yielding to the desires and whims of, especially to an excessive degree. To allow (oneself) unrestrained gratification.

Region of the Indus River, now in Pakistan, where in 1924 archeologists discovered the remains of a high civilization which flourished between 5000 and 1000 BCE. There, a "seal" was found with the effigy of Siva as Pashupati, "Lord of Creatures," seated in a yogic posture. Neither the language of these people nor their exact background is known. They related culturally and carried on an extensive trade with peoples of other civilizations, far to the West, using sturdy ships that they built themselves. For centuries they were the most advanced civilization on Earth.
To dwell or be in. "The priest asks the Deity to indwell the image," or come and inhabit the murti as a temporary physical body.
Not amenable or possible to be spoken of, described or expressed.
Impossible to avoid or prevent. Predictable.
Cannot be exhausted, used up or emptied. Tireless.
Impossible to explain or account for; inexcusable.
Cannot be disentangled or separated from another thing.
The magnetic condition of being captured by a foolish or shallow love or affection.
Deriving logical conclusions from premises assumed to be true.
A persistent sense of inadequacy or a tendency to self-depreciation.
One who has no religious beliefs, or who rejects a particular religion.
To gradually penetrate so as to counteract or seize control from within.
Infinitely small; too small to be measured.
To give or cause pain, wounds, damage, etc.
A flowing in. Mass arrival or incoming.
To transmit a quality, idea, knowledge, etc., as if by pouring. To impart, fill or inspire.
To take food, medicine, etc., into the body by swallowing or absorbing.
Inborn. Existing in someone or something as an essential or inseparable quality.  -- inherent sin:
To receive from an ancestor, as property, title, etc. -- or to reap from our own actions: "...seed karmas we inherit from this and past lives."
To hold back, restrain, prohibit or forbid. To suppress.
Entering into; admission as a member. In Hinduism, initiation from a qualified preceptor is considered invaluable for spiritual progress. Usually the beginning of more advanced learning.
An urging; an order or firm instruction.
A slight hint or indication.
Located deepest within.
Naturally occurring; not acquired. That which belongs to the inherent nature or constitution of a being or thing.
Located within. Of the depths of our being.
Progress of an individual at the soul level rather than in external life.
The subtle bodies of man within the physical body.

A moonlight-like glow that can be seen inside the head or throughout the body when the vrittis, mental fluctuations, have been sufficiently quieted. To be able to see and bask in the inner light is a milestone on the path.
The mind in its deeper, intuitive functions and capacities -- the subsuperconscious and superconscious.
Inner worlds or regions of existence.
The area of the mind which is clear inner space, free of mental images, feelings, identifications, etc. Tranquility itself. The superconscious mind, Satchidananda.
The astral and causal worlds.

Learning from within. A word coined by Sivaya Subramuniyaswami which indicates turning inward, through yoga concentration and meditation, to the vast superconscious state of mind; whence knowledge can be unfolded.
So many as to be beyond counting.
Exceeding reasonable limits; immoderate.
An advance, an encroachment, an incursion.
A sudden rushing in; an influx.
That cannot be analyzed or understood. Mysterious; beyond examining.
Plural of the Latin insigne. Signs or symbols of identity, rank or office, such as a badge, staff or emblem.

"Natural" or "innate." From the Latin instinctus, "impelling, instigating."In a religious context, instinctive and instinctiveness are used to describe the lower animal instincts of human nature as well as lower astral aspects of humans -- for example, self-preservation, procreation, hunger and thirst, also the emotions of greed, hatred, anger, fear, lust and jealousy. The first steps on the spiritual path consist in learning to harness these tendencies and impulses and transmute their energies into the higher nature.
Manas chitta. The lower mind, which controls the basic faculties of perception, movement, as well as ordinary thought and emotion. Manas chitta is of the manomaya kosha.
The mind in ordinary consciousness, when actions are based either upon instinctive emotional desires and fears or intellectual concepts and reason.
Sahakari karana. Cosmologically, the means of implementing creation.
To make certain, sure, or secure.
Remaining sound, entire, or uninjured; not impaired in any way.
Incapable of being perceived ("touched") by the senses.

The ability to reason or understand; power of thought; mental acumen. An intellectual is a person who has great mental abilities and intelligence. Such persons usually have control over their instinctive nature, but may not be awakened to their higher intuitive nature.

Buddhi chitta. The faculty of reason and logical thinking. It is the source of discriminating thought, rather than the ordinary, impulsive thought processes of the lower or instinctive mind, called manas chitta. Buddhi chitta is of the manomaya kosha.
A point at which independent systems (as in the physical and astral worlds) or diverse groups interact.
A time in between one event and another.
Interwoven; connected intricately.
A period of time between two events.
To mix or become mixed together.
To take something inside of oneself.
Yoga. Worship or contact with God and Gods via meditation and contemplation rather than through external ritual. This is the yogi's path, preceded by the charya and kriya padas.
Interaction between two or more factors.
An examination involving formal or official questioning.
To come between, especially two people or parties, with the intent to effect a change between them.
To weave together, as threads into cloth. To closely interrelate; to blend.
The state of being intimate or very close. Having a close rapport.
To utter with a singing tone or with a particular intonation.
Refusing to moderate a position, especially an extreme position; uncompromising.
A secret plot or scheme. To excite interest or curiosity.
Inward, essential; inherent. Belonging to the real nature of a being or thing.
"Looking inside." Examining one's own thoughts, feelings and sensations.
Turning within. Directing one's interest, mind or attention upon oneself.
The act of entering without permission.
To know or sense without resorting to rational processes.
Direct understanding or cognition, which bypasses the process of reason. Intuition is a far superior source of knowing than reason, but it does not contradict reason.
Consistently, constantly, unchangingly.
To give strength, life or energy.
That which cannot be overcome; unconquerable.
A "calling or summoning," as to a God, saint, etc., for blessings and assistance. Also, a formal prayer or chant.
"By the fact itself." A result accomplished by the deed itself, e.g. in some faiths declaring oneself apostate means ipso facto excommunication.
"Worshipful one; divine one." One of the most ancient Tamil appellations for God.

A chola-style white-granite Iraivan Temple, hand-carved in Bangalore, India, established on Hawaii's Garden Island of Kauai. In the sanctum sanctorum, the Supreme God, Siva (Parameshvara-Parashakti-Parashiva), will be enshrined as a massive 700-pound, single-pointed earthkeeper quartz crystal.
Impossible to resist. Having an overpowering appeal.
Disrespectful. Critical of what is generally accepted or respected.
In a manner not to be retracted, revoked or taken back.
"Darkness." The first of three stages of the sakala avasthai where the soul's impetus is toward pasha-jnanam, knowledge and experience of the world.

"Balance." The balance which emerges in the life of a soul in the stage of marul, or pashu-jnana, the second stage of the sakala avastha, when the soul turns toward the good and holy, becomes centered within himself, unaffected by the ups and downs in life.

"Balance." The balance which emerges in the life of a soul in the stage of marul, or pashu-jnanam, the second stage of the sakala avasthai, when the soul turns toward the good and holy, becomes centered within himself, unaffected by the ups and downs in life.
Saivite brahmin of the Kalamukha sect from whom Basavanna, principal founding teacher of Vira Saivism, received instruction in his youth.
"Lord, ruler or sovereign" master of all; superior, commanding, reigning. Isha and its derivative Ishana are very old names of God Siva found in the Rig Veda.
Last of the 40 chapters of Vajasaneyi Samhita of the Yajur Veda. A short, highly mystical scripture.

"Cherished or chosen Deity." The Deity that is the object of one's special pious attention. Ishta Devata is a concept common to all Hindu sects. Vaishnavas may choose among many Divine forms, most commonly Vishnu, Balaji, Krishna, Radha, Rama, Lakshmi, Hanuman and Narasinha, as well as the aniconic shalagrama, a sacred river rock. Traditionally, Smartas choose from among six Deities: Siva, Shakti, Vishnu, Surya, Ganesha and Kumara (or any of their traditional forms). For Shaktas, the Divine is worshiped as the Goddess, Shakti, in Her many fierce and benign forms, invoking the furious power of Kali or Durga, or the comforting grace of Parvati, Ambika and others. Saivites direct their worship primarily to Siva as represented by the aniconic Siva Linga, and the anthropomorphic murtis, Nataraja and Ardhanarishvara. In temples and scriptural lore, Siva is venerated in a multitude of forms, including the following 23 additional anthropomorphic images: Somaskanda, Rishabarudra, Kalyanasundara, Chandrashekhara, Bhikshatana, Kamadahanamurti, Kalari, Jalandara, Tripurari, Gajari, Virabhadra, Dakshinamurti, Kiratamurti, Nilakantha, Kankala, Chakradana, Gajamukhanugraha, Chandesanugraha, Ekapada, Lingodbhava, Sukhasana, Uma Maheshvara and Haryardha.

"Path-choosing rite." A temple ceremony held around age 18 in which a young man voices his decision to either enter the grihastha ashrama and accept the dharma of the householder, or in rare cases follow the dharma of the renunciate, beginning training as a monastic in preparation for taking holy orders of sannyasa.

"Cherished, chosen or personal mark of God." (Ishta: "sought, desired.") For Vira Saivites it is the personal Sivalinga, ceremonially given by a priest shortly after birth, and worn on a chain or cord around the neck thereafter.
"Highest Lord." Supreme or Personal God.
"Worship of God."

The religion founded by Prophet Mohammed in Arabia about 625 CE. Islam connotes submission to Allah, the name for God in this religion. Adherents, known as Muslims, follow the "Five Pillars" enjoined in their scripture, the Koran: faith in Allah, praying five times daily facing Mecca, giving of alms, fasting during the month of Ramadan, and pilgrimage. One of the fastest growing religions, Islam has over one billion followers, mostly in the Middle East, Pakistan, Africa, China, Indochina, Russia and neighboring countries.

A renowned pilgrimage site that devotees strive to visit at least once in a lifetime. Iraivan Temple is situated on the banks of the historically famous Wailua River on the Garden Island of Kauai in the Hawaii island chain.
To come out; be created. To start existing as an entity, e.g., as creation issues forth from Nataraja's drum.

"Devotion to God." Cultivating devotion through daily worship and meditation, the fifth of five niyamas listed by Sage Patanjali in his 2,200-year-old Yoga Sutras. Isvarapranidhana is essentially the equivalent of Isvarapujana (worship), the corresponding niyama listed in the Sandilya Upanishad and other texts which include ten niyamas rather than five.

"Worship of the Lord." Isvarapujana is worship, especially ritual worship known as puja in which devotion is expressed toward an image of the Deity. It is also internal worship, or meditation and is a traditional niyama of ashtanga yoga.

"So it was." Epic history, particularly the Ramayana and Mahabharata (of which the famed Bhagavad Gita is a part). This term sometimes refers to the Puranas, especially the Skanda Purana and the Bhagavata Purana (or Shrimad Bhagavatam).
Traveling from place to place, with no permanent home. Wandering.
A South Indian Vaishnavite brahmin caste.
A common name for brahmin priests, often a Smarta brahmin.
